title: Help: Using EDX Data
subtitle: Practical guardrails for day-to-day data use — fast to read, hard to misuse.
footer_note: All access is immutably logged. Policies (masking, ABAC) apply consistently across SQL, APIs, exports, and shares.

sections.title: Masking rules (what you’ll see)
sections.intro: Sensitive columns are dynamically masked based on classification and your effective policy.
points: PII_DIRECTORY → partially masked (e.g., last-4, initials) where allowed.
HEALTH / DISCIPLINE → de-identified unless purpose is approved.
Derived fields may be masked if they can re-identify individuals.
sections.note: Masking applies equally in the UI, SQL workbench, exports, and external BI tools.

sections.title: Purpose limits (why you’re using data)
sections.intro: Choose the closest matching purpose before running queries or exports.
points: Operational: daily district/institution tasks; least data necessary.
Compliance: reporting to state/federal agencies; approved extracts only.
Research: de-identified datasets; IRB may be required.
Accountability / Reporting: public or board reporting with strict aggregation.
sections.note: A mismatch between purpose and data scope triggers policy denial or de-identification.

sections.title: Exports etiquette (do this, not that)
points: Prefer publish views; avoid raw source exports.
Use filters (org, term, program) to keep extracts narrowly scoped.
Set a retention period that matches business need (e.g., 90 days).
Store exports in approved locations; never email PII as attachments.
Re-use previous request via “Reproduce export” to maintain consistency.
